comments.text:
the art of being daft, which you're all doing well at. it's not 'artsy' in 
its look to anyone outside of the bmx world. the bmx world that throws the 
term 'artsy' at anything with a bit of pretty normal footage. i'm not 
saying it's not pleasant to the eye, i'm not saying it's not art, i'm not 
saying i don't like and i'm not saying anything, as explained, other than 
fuck the worthless and unjust use of the term 'artsy'. if you don't 
understand this, you're dumb.

this so many times now and come to the conclusion that it's one of my 
favorite edits EVER. The combination of riding, filming, music and editing

comments.text:
I cannot write a normal Youtube comment for some reason. So I type a 
response. The city looks beautiful. And yeah the edit was beautiful. Great 
intro, lots of wheel hub sounds, slowed down at the right places. Nothing 
seemed forced. I hope even the skateparks are bigger in Texas.
comments.author: sunairjet

comments.text:
We're glad you enjoyed it, we did to. Big thanks to Joe Simon and The 
Delivery Men team for putting this edit together!
comments.author: Oakley

captions.text: It's really nothing...
No other feeling like riding.
Those moments when you're floating, time feels as though it stopped...
Everything else just washing away.
There's no noise, no traffic.
It's perfect.
Riding around in Austin is definitely where I'm in my element.
The city is so unique and diverse.
You have the trails, house park, literally hundreds of other places.
I, for the most part have been pedaling everywhere my entire life.
I'm one of the few BMX riders that was born and raised here in Austin.
I started riding at 7 years old.
and by 13/14 years old I remember watching legends like Joe, and Taj,
and Ruben by 9th street.
I obviously looked up to the way they rode,
but never imagined people would look up to me one day
I still feel like that kid on that bike...
It's been quite the journey, and it seems crazy that this bike has taken me all over the world.
But to come back have this your home is just...
Well, I consider myself one of the lucky ones.
